title: My Honest Take on Pineapple Tallow Balm: What Actually Happened to My Skin
body:
Okay so I was just sitting here, my foot was asleep from how I was sitting on the couch, and I was staring at this little jar on my coffee table. It’s this whipped tallow balm that smells like pineapple. Beef tallow. For your face. I know. It sounds like something you’d use to season a cast iron pan, not put on your skin. That was my exact thought back in, I don’t know, November maybe? It was already getting cold and my skin was doing that thing where it feels tight and looks sort of sad. Like it’s given up. I’d been using this fancy cream from one of those stores in the mall, the one that smells like a perfume counter and costs like eighty bucks. It did nothing. My skin just drank it up and asked for more. I was annoyed. So I was scrolling on my phone late one night, probably 11:47pm, and I kept seeing stuff about beef tallow skincare. People were saying it was this miracle thing. I was skeptical. Very. But my hands were so dry they were cracking by my knuckles and I was desperate. So I figured, what’s the weirdest thing that could happen.

I ordered the pineapple one from this little Etsy shop. The Whipped Tallow Balm. It said it was made in France from grass-fed beef suet, whipped up into this creamy stuff. The description said it mimics human skin sebum so it absorbs deep. I read that and thought, “Okay, science words, sure.” But the “tropical escape” scent description got me. It was the dead of winter. Everything was gray. I wanted to smell something that wasn’t rain or my neighbor’s fireplace. So I clicked buy. It was like, twenty-six dollars? Something like that. Not cheap, but way less than the mall cream that did nothing.

## How I Started Using Tallow on My Face (And Why It Was Weird)

It showed up in a little box. The jar itself is cute, I’ll give it that. Glass jar, simple label. I opened it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It’s solid but soft, like if cold butter and whipped cream had a baby. You scoop a tiny bit and it melts the second it hits your finger. I put a dab on the back of my hand first. Smelled like. I don’t know. Nice though. Not fake candy pineapple. More like if a pineapple was sitting in a sunny room. Sweet but clean. Cheerful. It made me think of a vacation I took like six years ago, which was a random memory to have at 9 PM on a Tuesday in my kitchen. Anyway, I rubbed it in. It vanished. No greasy film, no shiny residue. It was just… gone. And my skin felt different. Not moisturized in that heavy, sit-on-top way. It felt like my skin but calmer. Quieter. I was intrigued.

But putting beef fat on my *face* felt like a bridge too far. I started with my hands. My cracked knuckles. I’d use it after washing dishes. Within like, three days, the cracks were just… healing. No sting when I put it on. It just soaked in and fixed the problem. So I got brave. One night, after I washed my face with my regular drugstore cleanser (the Cetaphil one, the big pump bottle), my skin felt that tight, squeaky dry feeling. I looked at the tallow balm. I said out loud to my cat, “This is either genius or I’m about to break out in a historic way.” I took the tiniest amount, warmed it between my fingers, and just patted it all over my face. It felt… fine. A little slick for a second, then it sank in. I went to bed expecting to wake up a greaseball.

I didn’t. My skin in the morning was soft. Not “oh I just put cream on” soft. But like, my own skin was just… better. No new red spots. No clogged pores. It was the first hint that maybe this whole natural skincare routine with tallow wasn’t just internet nonsense.

## What This Pineapple Tallow Balm Actually Does (For Me, Anyway)

Look, I’m not a skincare person. I don’t have ten steps. My routine was: wash face, sometimes use a cream if I remembered, suffer in winter. This tallow balm daily use became the only thing I used after washing. That’s it. I’d get out of the shower, face still damp, and use a pea-sized amount for my whole face and neck. The scent is the best part in the morning. It’s this bright, sunny smell in the middle of gray winter gloom. It doesn’t smell like beef at all, which everyone asks. It just smells like happy fruit. It’s not strong, it fades pretty quick, but for a minute there it’s like a little mental vacation.

But the results are what got me. It’s not a dramatic transformation. I didn’t look ten years younger. My skin just… stopped being a problem. The dry, flaky patches on my cheeks? Gone in a week. The tight feeling all day? Never came back. My makeup (when I bother) sits better. It’s like my skin finally had what it needed, so it stopped freaking out. I think that’s the sebum-mimicking thing they talk about. It’s not adding a foreign layer of moisture; it’s giving your skin something it recognizes. Something it knows how to use. Switching to natural products always seemed like a hassle, but this was just one jar. One step.

And my hands! I keep a little sample pot by the sink now. My knuckles haven’t cracked once this whole season. My partner even started using it on his elbows because they were like sandpaper. He was skeptical too, called it my “cow cream,” but now he asks for it. I got one for my mom for Christmas. She has super sensitive skin and most lotions make her itch. She texted me last week saying it’s the only thing that doesn’t bother her. So that’s something.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

So it’s been a couple months now. I’m on my second jar. I just reordered from the same Etsy shop because why mess with what works. My skin is just… consistent. That’s the word. It’s not perfect. I still get a stress pimple if I have a big work thing. But the overall dryness, the winter discomfort, the feeling that I need to constantly apply something? Gone. It feels balanced. Healthy in a boring, non-glamorous way. My skin just does its job now.

The weirdest test was when I went to my parents’ house for a weekend. Forgot the jar. Used my mom’s fancy lotion. My skin felt okay while it was on, but by the next afternoon it was tight and thirsty again. I missed my tallow balm. I actually missed it. That’s when I knew I was a convert. It’s not that other stuff is bad. It’s that this one thing just works with my skin, not against it. It feels like maintenance, not a battle.

And the pineapple scent still makes me smile. It’s such a small, silly joy. Opening that jar in the morning feels like a tiny act of rebellion against the dreary weather. Like, ha, I smell like a tropical island even if I’m just going to the grocery store.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. From what I read and from my own face, it works because it’s really similar to the oils our skin makes naturally. So it absorbs deep instead of sitting on top. It’s like giving your skin back what it loses, especially in dry weather. My sensitive skin loves it.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was terrified of this. But no, not for me. It’s the opposite—it seems to absorb so completely that it doesn’t leave a pore-clogging film. The key is to use a tiny amount. A little goes a long, long way.

**What does the pineapple tallow balm smell like?**
It’s sweet but not a candy smell. It’s like fresh, ripe pineapple without being fake. It’s cheerful and bright. The scent doesn’t stick around all day, but when you first put it on, it’s a nice little mood boost.

Anyway. My coffee’s been cold for like twenty minutes. The point is, I was super skeptical about this whole tallow skincare thing. It sounded messy and weird. But this little jar of pineapple-scented balm fixed my dry winter skin when a bunch of expensive stuff didn’t. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. If your skin is being difficult and you’re curious about switching to something simple and natural, this might be worth a shot. I don’t know what else to say. It just works.
